author: Jason Ubay
title: Hawaii hotel occupancy remains stable as room rates rise 5 percent
text:
Hawaii hotel occupancy remains stable as room rates rise 5 percent Jul 17, 2015, 6:40am HST Share Jason Ubay Reporter Pacific Business News Hawaii hotels and resorts filled nearly as many rooms last week as they did a year ago while charging guests more. The statewide hotel occupancy rate dropped just 0.2 of a percentage point to 81.1 percent, while the average daily room rate jumped 5 percent to $262.48, according to Hospitality Advisors LLC and STR Inc. Oahu led all islands with 89.6 percent of its hotel inventory full, down 0.4 of a percentage point from the same week last year, while the average room rate grew 6.4 percent to $244.84. Maui, as usual, commanded the highest average room rate of all islands, charging customers an average of $331.18 a night, up 5.3 percent, while its hotels were 72.2 percent full, down half of a percentage point. Kauai had a 72.2 percent occupancy rate during the week ending July 11, down 3.6 percentage points, while the average room rate increased 5.3 percent to $267.60. The Big Island proved to be an anomaly, seeing its hotel occupancy rate rise 3.4 percentage points to 68.7 percent while the average room rate dipped 0.5 percent to $228.38. During the same week, the nationwide average hotel occupancy was 72.1 percent with an average daily room rate of $119.08. Los Angeles hotels were 81.7 percent full and charged customers an average of $158.33. Orlando hotels were 80 percent occupied and customers paid an average of $106.35 a night. San Diego hotels reported an occupancy rate of 80.7 percent with an average room rate of $119.08. Hospitality Advisors’ weekly hotel report is based on a daily survey generally consisting of approximately 100 Hawaii properties representing 40,744 rooms, or 71.5 percent of the state’s total hotel rooms for properties with 20 units or more. The daily hotel survey provides preliminary daily market information.
